qas.question: According to what, energy can neither be created nor destroyed by itself?
The total inflow of energy into a system must equal what?

answers.text: total outflow of energy from the system, plus the change in the energy contained within the system

qas.question: What can neither be created nor destroyed by itself; it can only be transformed?
According to what, energy can either be created or destroyed by itself?

plausible_answers.text: total inflow of energy into a system must equal the total outflow of energy from the system, plus the change in the energy contained within the system

qas.question: The total inflow of energy into a system must not equal what?
What can neither be created nor destroyed by itself and can't be transformed?
whose interactions depend explicitly on time?
total energy of the system never remains what?

context: According to <a0_0><b3_0>conservation of energy<b3_0/><a0_0/>, <a2_0><b5_0>energy<b5_0/><a2_0/> can neither be created (produced) nor destroyed by itself. It can only be transformed. The <b4_0>total inflow of energy into a system must equal the <a1_0>total outflow of energy from the system, plus the change in the energy contained within the system<b4_0/><a1_0/>. Energy is subject to a strict global conservation law; that is, whenever one measures (or calculates) the total energy of <b6_0>a system of particles<b6_0/> whose interactions do not depend explicitly on time, it is found that the total energy of the system always remains <b7_0>constant<b7_0/>.
